title: Does our consciousness die when we die, or is it a type of energy that continues to exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: These our consciousness questions drive me crazy. Consciousness is a process. Consciousness is not a thing, but a process of inference – Karl Friston | Aeon Essays Consciousness is like a spotlight that focuses on something. Right now you are conscious of reading Quora. Five minutes from now you may be conscious of something else and soon you will be asleep…unconscious. So, it’s not that we don’t know what consciousness is…we know very clearly what it is and being able to shine that light on something is, for us, completely dependent upon the brain. Steve DeBerry's answer to If consciousness is energy, and energy can't be destroyed, will our consciousness live as a different form of energy after death? Does the music continue after you turn off the radio? Though, we know what consciousness is, we don’t know why it exists or how it comes about…how it works. Nor, do we know where else it exists but we’re pretty sure our friends have it ( most of the time ) as well as our dogs or cats but when it comes to fruit flies, bacteria or plum trees we’re not really sure. Right now, I favor those who say that science will never provide an answer. Steve DeBerry's answer to What exists, that does not in plants or other microscopic organisms, in our anatomy that gives us consciousness? I’m also in favor of considering the idea that consciousness is more of a universal quality than we realize. Yet, there’s no way to know for sure until we die. Steve DeBerry's answer to Does consciousness take place outside the human brain? But let's, be honest with ourselves and replace the word consciousness in these questions with the words Me or I. Then the question becomes do I die when I die or am I a type of energy that continues to exist? Who knows? Maybe. the pantheist approach

What do you mean by consciousness? the subjective experience we have of the world? our personality? our memories? a combination of those things? Then yes, consciousness is gone when we die, it’s a property of the brain, a complex interplay between various structures within a very large neural network. If the network breaks, so do all the processes within it. “energy” isn’t much of a description here, it’s just a different word to bypass the need to give a definition, it’s not a definition in itself. The “energy” in your brain is made up of gradients or phosphor groups, much like a compressed spring has “energy”. It’s not some kind of “stuff” wizzing around up there.  (this image is wrong on so many levels) There’s no light pulses, no electricity, no “energy” in that sense in your head to make you you. It’s very much your brain, in your body, in your environment, with your past that makes you who you are. Once you die, all that is gone too, it breaks apart. It can be very difficult to accept, and most people don’t want to accept it, which is fine. Everyone is entitled to believe what they want to believe, doesn’t mean it corresponds to what’s actually going on though.

Consciousness is infinite and immortal. It is the energy of life itself. It does not belong to you, you belong to It. Consider that. Consider the sea of consciousness or the Quantum Field. Everything is created from this. It is ultimately the only reality. This is what you are. The body you call yours will cease to function at some point. The mind you call yours will cease to function at some point. But the consciousness that you really are will continue as it always has and always will. Some who die experience a continued sense of individuality and personality. Some willingly dissolve into the Infinite Sea of Consciousness. But ultimately, individuality is an illusion. The answer to your question could go on and on and hundreds of books have been written about it. Elisabeth Kubler-Ross wrote a number of them. The best one is called, On Death and Dying. It is certainly a worthy field of study and worth the time and energy. You cannot die. It is impossible. Consciousness is infinite and immortal. Even now, today, you can identify as the mind and body you call yours or you can expand your awareness of who and what you are and identify as the Infinite sea of Awareness that you truly are. Your choice. Take care Jon

The first problem, for those who believe that when we die then that is the end, is that science has shown that matter is not real. Einstein made this point when he said “Concerning matter, we have been all wrong. What we have called matter is energy, whose vibration has been so lowered as to be perceptible to the senses. There is no matter.” Bohr also said something consistent with this. If the material body is not made of real things then how is it that we really die? The second problem is one that was discovered in Tibet many years ago. Tibet is very high and cold and so when people die it is possible to leave the bodies for extended periods before burial. What was noticed was that after exactly 49 days, some of the corpses started talking. In a few rare cases the corpses reanimated, but mostly they talked for a few days and then stopped. This happened frequently enough for scribes to be summoned, who wrote down what the corpses said. Usually it was a description of what happened after death. These decriptions have been integrated into some Tibetan Buddhist teachings on what happens after death. However what it means is that something continues to exist after death.

Neither. I don’t presume to know all about everybody’s afterlife. I don’t even presume to know all about my own afterlife. But I had the bad luck to have a cardiac arrest and the good luck to have it in a hospital that specializes in bringing back people neurologically intact. I was gone for 12 minutes. I seem to have my senses. Things don’t have to be either matter or energy. There’s apparently “mind.” Your “mind” always exists. Your brain is just too busy keeping your body alive so you can have new experiences to add to the total of universal experience for you to notice it. I think we’re always where we go in the “after” life. I think we just don’t realize while we’re busy living this one.

Consciousness isn’t a “type of energy” or a mysterious substance or force that exists independent of the brain. Rather, it is a highly complex process that arises from the information processing activities going on in our brains. A very rough analogy would be to a video game being a process that is generated by the information processing activities running in a computer. When the computer is turned off, the information processing activities come to a halt and the video game stops. It doesn’t go anywhere else or continue to exist independently of the CPU. The same is true of our consciousness with respect to our brains. When the brain dies, consciousness ceases to exist.

There is no evidence that we do, and no evidence that we don’t. Nor do we know what consciousness is or how it originated. It’s like asking what was I before I was born, and what will I be after I die. Here is a good outline of how little we know. David Chalmers at Ted Talks. How do you explain consciousness? So what do you mean when you say “I”?
